codeExamples.title: ADC background scan source
codeExamples.name: ADC_Background_Scan_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Background Scan mode of the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) module is configured to measure the
analog signals applied to the channels 4 to 7 of the group 4.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC background scan source
codeExamples.name: ADC_Background_Scan_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The Background Scan mode of the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) module is configured to measure the
analog signals applied to the channels 0 to 3 of the group 0.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC filtering
codeExamples.name: ADC_Filtering_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) module is configured to convert four channels in
background scan mode. The data resulting from the conversions of three channels is automatically
modified: one channel computes an average on 4 results, another channel applies a 3rd order
Finite Impulse Response (FIR) filter and another channel applies a 1st order
Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) filter. Finally, the last channel measures the same signal without
Data Modification. The channels are continuously converted and, for each of them, the maximum
and minimum values are stored, which are then sent through UART in order to be compared.
codeExamples.abstract: Four VADC channels are used to convert the same analog signal with different filters enabled.

codeExamples.title: Auto Scan of ADC channel
codeExamples.name: ADC_Group_Scan_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Auto Scan mode of the Versatile Analog to Digital Converter (VADC) module is enabled over the
channels 0 to 4 of the Group 0. Additionally, the converted results are checked with the
Valid Flag (VF) of the Result Register, and then sent to the PC via UART.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using  scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC single channel conversion
codeExamples.name: ADC_Single_Channel_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
An analog input channel is continuously converted using the background scan mode.
The input value is determined by the potentiometer on the board.
Two LEDs are used to indicate a voltage interval.
Thus depending on the conversion value, one or both LEDs are on.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure an analog signal using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC single channel conversion
codeExamples.name: ADC_Single_Channel_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
An analog input channel is continuously converted using the background scan mode. The input value
is determined using the microcontroller's supply voltage, ground level or letting the analog pin open
and floating. Three LEDs are used, each indicating a voltage interval. Thus depending on the conversion
value, a certain LED will light up.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure an analog signal using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: Shell via UART communication
codeExamples.name: ASCLIN_Shell_UART_1_KIT_TC237_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The ASCLIN module is configured for UART communication.
The Shell from iLLDs exploits the ASCLIN module to interpret and manage commands from the
user like "info", "toggle [x]" or "help".
codeExamples.abstract: A Shell is used to parse a command line and call the corresponding command execution. The ASCLIN module is used to interface with the Shell through the USB port via UART.

codeExamples.title: Register Access Protection
codeExamples.name: BUS_Register_Protection_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CPU0 tries to make a write access to an ASCLIN0 module register two times: when the access is
enabled for CPU0 and when the access is disabled for CPU0. During the second register write access,
a Trap is expected to be raised, to inform about the illegal write access.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to protect registers from unintended write access by using AURIX register access protection mechanisms.

The CPU0 tries to make a write access to an ASCLIN0 module register two times: when the access is
enabled for CPU0 and when the access is disabled for CPU0. During the second register write access,
a Trap is expected to be raised, to inform about the illegal write access.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to protect registers from unintended write access by using AURIX register access protection mechanisms.

codeExamples.title: CCU6 ADC conversion triggering
codeExamples.name: CCU6_ADC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Timer T12 is defining the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) sample rate. Due to the instability of
the signals (e.g. the overshoot period), a delay is introduced by Timer T13 after each period match of
Timer T12. This ensures that the measurement is done when the signal is already stable. UART
communication is used to display all measured values on a terminal monitor.
codeExamples.abstract: CCU6 timers T12 and T13 are used to trigger the Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: CCU6_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Timer T12 of the CCU6 unit generates an interrupt on a "period match" event every 500 ms.
Inside the ISR, a counter variable is incremented. The LEDs toggle based on the value of the counter:
- LED1 on and LED2 off: counter % 2 == 0
- LED1 off and LED2 on: counter % 2 == 1
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit generates an interrupt every 500 ms and increments a counter in its Interrupt Service Routine (ISR).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: CCU6_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Timer T12 of the CCU6  unit generates an interrupt on a "period match" event every 500 ms.
Inside the ISR, a counter variable is incremented.
LEDs toggles based on the value of the counter:
- 1st LED: counter % 4 == 0
- 2nd LED: counter % 4 == 1
- 3rd LED: counter % 4 == 2
- 4th LED: counter % 4 == 3
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit generates an interrupt every 500 ms and increments a counter in its Interrupt Service Routine (ISR).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 PWM signal capture
codeExamples.name: CCU6_PWM_Capture_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A simple PWM signal is generated by toggling a port pin. The resulting PWM frequency and duty cycle
is measured by the Capture/Control Unit 6 (CCU6).
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit is used to capture an external PWM signal and calculate its frequency and duty cycle.

codeExamples.title: Generation of PWM via CCU6
codeExamples.name: CCU6_PWM_Generation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The code example uses the Timer T12 of CCU6 and its three compare modules to generate three PWM signals
with a frequency of 20 kHz and different duty cycles (25%, 50% and 75%). T12 is configured to count up
and down and the three signals are center aligned. The generated PWM signals are sent to the pins
available on the board and can be observed with an oscilloscope.
codeExamples.abstract: Three center aligned Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) signals with fixed frequency and different duty cycles are generated using CCU6.

codeExamples.title: Clock configuration via CCU
codeExamples.name: CCU_Clock_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:

codeExamples.abstract: The clock system is configured based on a PLL frequency of 200 MHz and the clock signal is provided at an external port pin.

codeExamples.title: CPU performance counters
codeExamples.name: CPU_Perf_Counters_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CPU performance counters are counting the number of instructions, clock ticks and multi
counters ticks. They are used to measure the run-time of a c-function.
The result is stored in a global variable.
codeExamples.abstract: Measure code performance via the CPU performance counters

codeExamples.title: TRAP error recognition and reaction
codeExamples.name: CPU_Trap_Recognition_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The tutorial describes what types of traps are supported by the AURIX microcontroller, their root
causes and how to identify them. AURIX architecture supports different types of traps. Three different
traps can be provoked with this example and the tutorial guides the user through the needed steps to
observe the root cause of each trap.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to identify the root cause of a trap.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer of ADC conversion results
codeExamples.name: DMA_ADC_Transfer_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
At the end of an analog-to-digital conversion of the VADC module, an interrupt is triggered, which starts
the data transfer of the converted ADC results via DMA to the LMURAM. The ADC conversion is started
manually via a command of a serial monitor.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ADC measurements results to LMURAM.

codeExamples.title: DMA Linked List Mode usage
codeExamples.name: DMA_Linked_List_Mode_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this training, four DMA transactions are configured in DMA Linked List mode.
Triggering one DMA transaction leads to the execution of all DMA transactions consecutively.
An interrupt is triggered at the completion of the last DMA transaction.
If DMA has correctly transferred the data, the LED driven by port pin 00.6 toggles and a new cycle
starts again. Otherwise, the LED driven by port pin 00.5 turns ON and no more DMA transfers are done.
codeExamples.abstract: DMA Linked Lists are used to execute a series of DMA transactions without CPU intervention.

codeExamples.name: DMA_Linked_List_Mode_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:

starts again. Otherwise, the LED driven by port pin 13.2 turns ON and no more DMA transfers are done.
codeExamples.abstract: DMA Linked Lists are used to execute a series of DMA transactions without CPU intervention.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer between memories
codeExamples.name: DMA_Mem_to_Mem_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The transfer of data is triggered by SW. The source is the Data Scratch Pad SRAM of CPU0 (DSPR0) and
the destination is the Local Memory Unit (LMURAM). At the end of the transactions, the data is
verified by comparing the source and destination buffers. The success of the data transfer is signaled
through the LED connected to pin 6 of port 00. Otherwise, the LED connected to pin 5 of port 00 is
used. The same cycle is repeated each second.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ten words (32-bit) of data from one memory location to another without any CPU load.

codeExamples.name: DMA_Mem_to_Mem_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:

through the LED connected to pin 0 of port 13. Otherwise, the LED connected to pin 1 of port 13 is
used. The same cycle is repeated each second.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ten words (32-bit) of data from one memory location to another without any CPU load.

codeExamples.title: Delta-Sigma ADC conversion
codeExamples.name: DSADC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Delta-Sigma ADC (DSADC) continuously measures an external signal on channel 0, connected
to port pin AN2. It converts the analog signal to a data stream and then a global variable is updated
to the current conversion result.
codeExamples.abstract: The DSADC is used to convert an external signal to a stream of discrete digital values.

codeExamples.name: DSADC_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:

codeExamples.title: Enhanced Delta-Sigma ADC conversion
codeExamples.name: EDSADC_1_KIT_TC375_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Enhanced Delta-Sigma ADC (EDSADC) continuously measures an external signal on channel 3, connected
to port pin AN0. It converts the analog signal to a data stream and then a global variable is updated
to the current conversion result. The input value is determined by the potentiometer on the board.
codeExamples.abstract: The EDSADC is used to convert an external signal to a stream of discrete digital values.

codeExamples.title: External interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: ERU_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The code example uses the External Request Unit (ERU) to generate an interrupt for each
falling and rising edge at an input pin. The falling and rising edges are generated
with the pin P00.7 connected to the boardï¿½s button. If an interrupt occurs, an LED will be toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The ERU is used to generate an interrupt on each rising and falling edge at an input pin.

codeExamples.title: External interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: ERU_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The code example uses the External Request Unit (ERU) to generate an interrupt for each
falling and rising edge at the input pin P02.0. The falling and rising edges are generated
with pin P02.1. If an Interrupt occurs, an LED will be toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The ERU is used to generate an interrupt on each rising and falling edge at an input pin.

codeExamples.title: Ethernet communication
codeExamples.name: Ethernet_1_KIT_TC375_LK
codeExamples.description:
The TCP/IP protocol provided by the Lightweight IP (LwIP) is used to exchange strings between the board
and a remote client terminal.
The board obtains an IP address and publishes its hostname using the DHCP protocol.
The System Timer Module (STM) is used to update the internal LwIP timers.
The Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module is used for debug logging.
codeExamples.abstract: The Gigabit Ethernet Media Access Controller (GETH) module and the Lightweight IP (LwIP) stack are used to implement a network echo application.

codeExamples.title: FCE CRC calculation
codeExamples.name: FCE_CRC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
This training shows how to configure the FCE to calculate CRC of a known message
with all supported algorithms (CRC32, CRC16 and CRC8).
The FCE interrupt is enabled to report execution errors.
Any CRC kernel calculation error is indicated by switching ON a different combinations of LEDs.
codeExamples.abstract: The FCE module is used to calculate the CRC of the same message with different algorithms.

codeExamples.title: Flash programming
codeExamples.name: Flash_Programming_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this example, 64 Bytes of the Program Flash memory (PFLASH) are flashed and verified afterwards.
Furthermore, 64 Bytes of the Data Flash memory (DFLASH) are flashed and verified. Before any write
operation, the flash memories are erased. If the flash operation is successful, an LED for each tested
memory is turned ON.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to flash the Program Flash memory and the Data Flash memory.

codeExamples.title: LED controlled via a push button
codeExamples.name: GPIO_LED_Button_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Upon pressure of a push button, an LED is turned on and the LED is turned off when releasing the button.
One port pin is configured as input for checking the push button state
and the other port pin is configured as output to control the LED.
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is controlled via a push button.

codeExamples.title: LED controlled via a push button
codeExamples.name: GPIO_LED_Button_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Upon pressure of a push button, an LED is turned on and the LED is turned off when
releasing the button. One port pin is configured as input for checking the push button
state and the other port pin is configured as output to control the LED.
Short the port pins P14.4 with P14.5 (pin 39 and 40 of header X102) to switch on the LED D110.
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is controlled via a push button.

codeExamples.title: Capture of PWM signal via GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_PWM_Capture_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
GPT12 timers are configured in capture mode. The data from the captured PWM signal is used to calculate
the PWM frequency in software. The frequency is then stored in a variable.
codeExamples.abstract: The GPT12 unit is used to capture an external PWM signal and calculate the PWM frequency.

codeExamples.title: Generation of PWM via GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_PWM_Generation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The timer T3 of GPT1 is used in timer mode with its count direction configured to "down-counting".
On underflow of timer T3, the Output Toggle Latch (T3OTL) is toggled and the value of timer T2
or T4 is transferred into timer T3 depending on T3OTL value. The state of an LED is toggled in an
interrupt service routine which is triggered by the timer T3.
codeExamples.abstract: A pulse width modulated (PWM) signal with fixed frequency and a defined duty cycle is generated using GPT12.

codeExamples.title: Timer concatenation of GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_Timer_Concatenation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A 32-bit timer is formed by the concatenation of two 16-bit timers of the GPT12 module.
When the 32-bit timer overflows, an interrupt is generated toggling an LED.
codeExamples.abstract: A 32-bit timer is formed by the concatenation of two timers of the GPT12 module. On timer overflow an interrupt is generated, which toggles an LED.

codeExamples.title: Read external device MAC address via I2C
codeExamples.name: I2C_Read_Ext_Device_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
An I2C module configured as I2C master is used to read the MAC address stored in MCP79411,
a Real-Time-Clock device mounted on the board KIT_AURIX_TC297_TFT_BC-Step. The AURIX
device reads the MAC address through the I2C module and stores it into a global variable.
codeExamples.abstract: An I2C module configured as I2C master is used to read a register of an external device.

codeExamples.title: Interrupts prioritization
codeExamples.name: Interrupt_Prio_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Each interrupt sends a message on a terminal when the ISR starts and ends.
In this example, the interrupts are triggered by GPT12 module.
codeExamples.abstract: Three interrupts, with different priorities each, send a message on a terminal using UART communication.

codeExamples.title: Interrupts prioritization
codeExamples.name: Interrupt_Prio_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Each interrupt is configured to control the state of one LED.
Based on their priority, the interrupts toggle the appropriate LED.
In this example, the interrupts are triggered by GPT12 module.
codeExamples.abstract: Three interrupts with different priorities are used to toggle LEDs.

codeExamples.title: PWM monitor via IOM
codeExamples.name: IOM_PWM_Monitor_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The PWM signal is routed through the port to the Input Output Monitor (IOM) module.
Its duty cycle is continuously compared with a threshold. If the value of the duty cycle goes
below the threshold, an LED is switched on.
codeExamples.abstract: A PWM signal's duty cycle is monitored using the IOM module.

codeExamples.name: IOM_PWM_Monitor_1_KIT_TC297_TFT

codeExamples.title: Comparison of signals via IOM
codeExamples.name: IOM_Signals_Comparison_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Two PWM signals are routed through the port pins to the Input Output Module (IOM) as monitor and
reference respectively. The signals are continuously compared using exclusive OR. If the newly formed
signal (XOR) is in high state outside the acceptable propagation window, an LED is switched on.
codeExamples.abstract: Two PWM signals are compared by the IOM module.

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN data transmission
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
A CAN message is sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode. After the CAN message
transmission, an interrupt is generated and an LED is turned on to confirm successful message
transmission. Once the CAN message is successfully received by the CAN node 1, an interrupt is
generated. Inside the interrupt service routine the content of the received CAN message is compared to
the content of the transmitted CAN message. In case of a success, another LED is turned on to confirm
successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MCMCAN is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN FD data transmission
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_FD_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode. Both CAN nodes are set
to CAN Flexible Data-rate mode (CAN FD). After each CAN message transmission and successful reception,
an interrupt is generated. Inside the interrupt service routine, the content of the received CAN
message is read. In case of the successful read operation, the received data is compared to the
transmitted data. If all messages are received without any error detected, the LED is turned on to
confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MCMCAN in Flexible Data-Rate mode is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN acceptance filtering
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_Filtering_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
Each transmitted CAN message contains a different message ID and based on the filter configuration,
the message is either accepted or rejected by CAN node 1. Messages that passed acceptance filtering
are stored in RX FIFOs 0 and 1 or dedicated RX buffer based on the filter configuration. Upon storing
the messages, the interrupt service routine is called and the content of the received CAN message is
read. Once the content of all the received messages is read, the received data is compared to the
transmitted data. If all messages are received without any error detected, an LED is turned on to
confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: The initialization and configuration of several filter modes are used to illustrate different acceptance filtering options.

codeExamples.title: Memory access performance
codeExamples.name: Memory_Access_Performance_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A routine is implemented to execute performance measurements using the CPU performance counters.
The amount of required CPU clocks is evaluated for ten alternating write and read operations to different
memories (DSPR0, DSPR1, LMU).
codeExamples.abstract: Data is stored and read back from different RAM locations while the access times are monitored using the CPU performance counters.

codeExamples.title: MPU memory protection
codeExamples.name: MPU_Memory_Protection_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The MPU module is configured to enable read/write access to the first half of an array.
To test the function of the read protection, each element of the array is read in a loop.
Two LEDs are used to indicate the progression of the CPU read accesses.
When the loop reads the last accessible element, the first LED is turned on.
The second LED is only turned on if the CPU reads an element which should be protected.
codeExamples.abstract: The MPU module is used to protect part of an array from read/write accesses.

codeExamples.title: Memory Built-In Test via MTU
codeExamples.name: MTU_MBIST_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this training the Memory Test Unit (MTU) is used to initialize and clear the content of an SRAM
memory including its ECC code. Also, the non destructive inversion test is performed by Memory
Built-in-Self-Test (MBIST) to verify the content of the same SRAM memory. The SRAM of the DMA
(DMARAM) is selected to be tested in this example. In order to test the faulty scenario, this training
provides the possibility to inject a single bit error in the memory. The LEDs on the board are used to
signal the correct or faulty behavior of the MBIST.
codeExamples.abstract: The MBIST is used to assess the state of the memory

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A CAN message is sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
After the CAN message transmission, an interrupt will be generated and LED1 will
be turned on to confirm successful message transmission. Once the CAN message
is successfully received by the CAN node 1, an interrupt will be generated.
Inside the interrupt service routine the content of the received CAN message will be
compared to the content of the transmitted CAN message. In case of a success, LED2
will be turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN in GATEWAY mode using TX FIFO
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_GW_TX_FIFO_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 2 over CAN bus (in case of Loop-Back
mode all nodes can access the internal bus). CAN node 0 receives the transmitted
messages but also immediately gateways the received data to CAN node 1. Three
message objects allocated to CAN node 1 define a TX FIFO buffer structure.
Immediately, upon the reception of the data via gateway, CAN node 1 transmits
the received data. The data transmitted by the CAN node 1 is received by the CAN
node 3. The content of the received data will be compared to the content of the
transmitted CAN messages together with the FIFO status check and in case of success,
a LED is turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN in Gateway mode is used to exchange data using a gateway with a TX FIFO structure between multiple nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN in GATEWAY mode using TX FIFO
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_GW_TX_FIFO_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 2 over CAN bus (in case of Loop-Back
mode all nodes can access the internal bus). CAN node 0 receives the transmitted
messages but also immediately gateways the received data to CAN node 1. Three
message objects allocated to CAN node 1 define a TX FIFO buffer structure.
Immediately, upon the reception of the data via gateway, CAN node 1 transmits
the received data. The data transmitted by the CAN node 1 is received by the CAN
node 3. The content of the received data will be compared to the content of the
transmitted CAN messages together with the FIFO status check and in case of success,
a LED is turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN in Gateway mode is used to exchange data using a gateway with a TX FIFO structure between multiple nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN RX FIFO data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_RX_FIFO_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 over CAN bus (in case of Loop-Back mode all nodes can access
the internal bus). CAN node 1 receives the transmitted messages and stores them inside of RX FIFO
buffer structure. Once the RX FIFO buffer threshold value has been reached, an interrupt service
request is generated. CPU 1 handles the interrupt service request and reads the received CAN messages
from the RX FIFO buffer. The content of the received data will be compared to the content of the
transmitted CAN messages and in case of success, an LED is turned on to confirm the message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN is used to exchange data using RX FIFO structure between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN RX FIFO data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_RX_FIFO_1_KIT_TC297_TFT

request is generated. CPU 1 handles the interrupt service request and reads the received CAN messages

codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN is used to exchange data using RX FIFO structure between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: Multicore LED control
codeExamples.name: Multicore_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:

Core 2 is controlling the state of the LED flag.

codeExamples.title: Power saving in CPU idle mode
codeExamples.name: PMS_Power_Down_Idle_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Power Management System (PMS) allows activation of power down modes for each CPU individually
in case there are no active tasks to perform and power consumption needs to be reduced.
In this example, the System Timer periodically generates interrupts (every two seconds). In the
Interrupt Service Routine, the CPU0 is switched between idle mode and run mode. CPU0 toggles LED1
during run mode whereas the LED1 remains in the last toggling state while CPU0 is idling.
codeExamples.abstract: CPU0 switches periodically between run mode and idle mode triggered by STM timer

codeExamples.title: Power Saving in Sleep Mode
codeExamples.name: PMS_Power_Down_Sleep_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
An STM timer generates an interrupt on the CPU0 every two seconds, switching the AURIX device from
run mode to sleep mode and vice versa. A GTM timer, responsible for toggling an LED, is then allowed to
go into sleep mode, thus stopping the LED from blinking. Two seconds later, the board is switched back
into run mode and the LED blinks again.
codeExamples.abstract: The system is set into sleep mode and it is waken up by the System Timer Module (STM) every 2 seconds.

codeExamples.title: PWM controlled melody on Buzzer
codeExamples.name: PWM_Buzzer_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The generated PWM (Pulse-Width Modulation) signal is controlled by timer TOM1 of the GTM block.
The signal drives the piezo buzzer via the pin 0 of the port 33.
codeExamples.abstract: The GTM unit is used to play a PWM-controlled song with a piezo buzzer.

codeExamples.title: Function running from RAM
codeExamples.name: RAM_Run_Function_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
This example implements twice the same function which toggles an LED with a wait loop.
One function is implemented to be executed from SRAM and the other one from Flash memory.
The SRAM function is toggling LED1 (P00.5), while the flash function is toggling LED2 (P00.6).
codeExamples.abstract: A function is stored and executed from SRAM.

codeExamples.title: Clock configuration via SCU
codeExamples.name: SCU_Clock_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Clock Control Unit, which is part of the System Control Units (SCU), is used to configure
the PLL clock. This clock signal is routed to an external clock output pin, which can be observed
with an oscilloscope.
codeExamples.abstract: The clock system is configured based on a PLL frequency of 200 MHz and the clock signal is provided at an external port pin.

codeExamples.title: Die Temperature Sensor
codeExamples.name: SCU_Die_Temp_Sensor_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The internal Die Temperature Sensor (DTS) is continuously read in an infinite loop.
When a new temperature result is available an interrupt service routine (ISR) is triggered.
The ISR notifies the availability of a new die temperature value by setting a flag,
which is used to start printing the temperature via UART communication using the
ASCLIN module. The temperature value can be read by using a terminal program
connected to the virtual COM port of the board/kit.
codeExamples.abstract: The die temperature is measured by an internal sensor and printed on a terminal program

codeExamples.title: Emergency Stop via SCU
codeExamples.name: SCU_Emergency_Stop_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The LED1, which is driven by the port pin P00.5, is blinking until an external signal
triggers an emergency stop and sets the pin to emergency stop mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to trigger an emergency stop via an external signal and how port pins can be set to a defined state in this case.

codeExamples.title: Power Saving in Standby Mode
codeExamples.name: SCU_Power_Down_Standby_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
This example shows how to set the microcontroller in power saving mode standby. The standby mode
is triggered via a SW request by writing into the Power Management Control and Status Register. The
system is woken up from standby mode using PinA (port pin 14.1) and can be controlled by a terminal
program.
codeExamples.abstract: Set the system to standby mode and use an external trigger signal on PinA to return to active mode.

codeExamples.title: Detection of reset type
codeExamples.name: SCU_Reset_Detection_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The AURIXï¿½ TC2xx devices can be reset by various reset sources.
The application software is able to determine the source of the last reset based on a routine
that evaluates the related reset special function registers. According to the type of reset,
one or two LEDs are switched on.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to detect the source of the last reset (power-on reset, watchdog reset, etc.)

codeExamples.title: Emergency stop triggered by an SMU alarm
codeExamples.name: SMU_Emergency_Stop_Alarm_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Safety Management Unit (SMU) is configured to trigger an interrupt if an internal software alarm
occurs. In case of an alarm, an LED is turned on inside the Interrupt Service Routine and the port
emergency stop is activated.
codeExamples.abstract: The SMU triggers an alarm, which has, as preconfigured reaction, an interrupt and a port emergency stop. The interrupt turns on an LED.

codeExamples.title: Fault signaling via a port pin
codeExamples.name: SMU_Fault_Signaling_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
After initialization the FSP is set to fault free state, indicated by a high level of the
port pin P33.8. After some time, the software triggers an alarm that leads to the FSP fault state,
thus the port pin P33.8 switches to low level state.
After 500 ms from triggering the alarm, the FSP release command is sent by software.
The minimum fault state time is configured to 2 s. Therefore the port pin P33.8 state switches to
high level again after 1500 ms.
codeExamples.abstract: The Fault Signaling Protocol (FSP) pin is configured by the SMU to signal a fault by changing the state of the port pin P33.8.

codeExamples.title: Fault signaling via a port pin
codeExamples.name: SMU_Fault_Signaling_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
After initialization the FSP is set to fault free state, indicated by a high level of the
port pin P33.8. After some time, the software triggers an alarm that leads to the FSP fault state,
thus the port pin P33.8 switches to low level state.
After 500 ms from triggering the alarm, the FSP release command is sent by software.
The minimum fault state time is configured to 2 s. Therefore the port pin P33.8 state switches to
high level again after 1500 ms.
codeExamples.abstract: The Fault Signaling Protocol (FSP) pin is configured by the SMU to signal a fault by changing the state of the port pin P33.8.

codeExamples.title: Fault signaling via a port pin
codeExamples.name: SMU_Fault_Signaling_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
During initialization the FSP is set to fault free state, indicated by a high level of the port pin
P33.8. The software triggers an alarm that leads to the FSP fault state, thus the port pin P33.8
switches to low level state. After one second from triggering the alarm, the FSP release command
is sent by software. The port pin P33.8 state switches to high level after the command is sent.
codeExamples.abstract: The Fault Signaling Protocol (FSP) pin is configured by the SMU to signal a fault by changing the state of the port pin P33.8.

codeExamples.description:
During initialization the FSP is set to fault free state, indicated by a high level of the port pin
P33.8. The software triggers an alarm that leads to the FSP fault state, thus the port pin P33.8
switches to low level state. After one second from triggering the alarm, the FSP release command
is sent by software. The port pin P33.8 state switches to high level after the command is sent.
codeExamples.abstract: The Fault Signaling Protocol (FSP) pin is configured by the SMU to signal a fault by changing the state of the port pin P33.8.

codeExamples.title: Interrupt triggered by an SMU alarm
codeExamples.name: SMU_IR_Alarm_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Safety Management Unit (SMU) is configured to trigger an interrupt if an internal software alarm
occurs. In case of an alarm, an LED will be turned on inside the Interrupt Service Routine.
codeExamples.abstract: The SMU triggers an alarm, which has, as preconfigured reaction, an interrupt. The interrupt turns on an LED.

codeExamples.title: SPI communication via QSPI
codeExamples.name: SPI_CPU_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
QSPI1 is configured in master mode and used to send five bytes to QSPI3 configured in slave mode.
The received data is read by the CPU and compared against the transmitted data. Port pin 00.5,
to which LED1 is connected, indicates the successful transfer.
codeExamples.abstract: A QSPI module configured as SPI master sends five bytes to another QSPI module which is configured as SPI slave.

codeExamples.title: SPI communication via QSPI
codeExamples.name: SPI_CPU_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
QSPI2 is configured in master mode and used to send five bytes to QSPI3 configured in slave mode.
The received data is read by the CPU and compared against the transmitted data. Port pin 13.3,
to which LED D110 is connected, indicates the successful transfer.
codeExamples.abstract: A QSPI module configured as SPI master sends five bytes to another QSPI module which is configured as SPI slave.

codeExamples.title: SPI data communication via DMA
codeExamples.name: SPI_DMA_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
This example implements an SPI full duplex communication.
QSPI1 is configured as an SPI master and QSPI3 is configured as an SPI slave. Both master and slave exchange eight bytes of data.
Four DMA channels are used to enable data transfer between RAM and QSPI FIFOs without CPU intervention:
DMA channel 1 is configured as SPI master Tx
DMA channel 2 is configured as SPI master Rx
DMA channel 3 is configured as SPI slave Tx
DMA channel 4 is configured as SPI slave Rx
An LED is used to signal the successful data communication.
codeExamples.abstract: QSPI is used to conduct SPI Master Slave communication using the DMA module.

codeExamples.description:

codeExamples.title: QSPI communication with TLF35584
codeExamples.name: SPI_TLF_1_KIT_TC397_TFT
codeExamples.description:
QSPI2 is configured in master mode and used to send data frames to TLF35584 device via SPI protocol.
The TLF35584 device is set to the NORMAL state and, in case of success, the LED D104 is turned on.
This training focuses on the SPI communication between QSPI module and TLF35548 device.
Typical application use case and the features of the TLF35584 device are not covered by this training.
codeExamples.abstract: A QSPI module configured as SPI master communicates with the TLF35584 device via SPI protocol.

codeExamples.title: Interrupt generation via STM trigger
codeExamples.name: STM_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC234_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The System Timer (STM) module counts up to a configured compare value, when it reaches the specific
value, it triggers an interrupt and resets its counter value. The value is set to trigger the interrupt
every 500 ms; at each interrupt an LED is toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The STM is configured to trigger an interrupt every 500 ms. The interrupt toggles an LED.

codeExamples.title: System time via STM
codeExamples.name: STM_System_Time_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The System Timer (STM) module counts the number of ticks since the last Application Reset.
This number is used to calculate the current system time in day, hours, minutes and seconds.
codeExamples.abstract: The STM module is used to get the current system time (days:hours:minutes:seconds). The time is stored in a structure.

codeExamples.title: UART data transfer via DMA
codeExamples.name: UART_DMA_Transfer_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CPU sends a message via UART in loopback mode. When it receives the message back,
it triggers an interrupt which starts the data transfer via DMA.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA module is used to transfer data received from the UART to LMURAM.

codeExamples.title: UART communication between PC and device
codeExamples.name: UART_VCOM_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The string "Hello World!" is sent from the device to the PC via UART.
The string is then visualized in a serial monitor.
codeExamples.abstract: UART communication via ASCLIN is used to send "Hello World!" from the device to the computer.
